demo.name: SameGame
demo.description: This demo shows how to write a 'Same Game' game in QML, using Javascript for all the game logic.

demo.name: Flickr Client
demo.description: This demo shows how to write a mobile Flickr browser application in QML.

demo.name: Affine Transformations
demo.description: In this demo we show Qt's ability to perform affine transformations on painting operations.

demo.name: Composition Modes
demo.description: This demo shows some of the more advanced composition modes supported by Qt.

demo.name: Gradients
demo.description: In this demo we show the various types of gradients that can be used in Qt.

demo.name: Path Stroking
demo.description: In this demo we show some of the various types of pens that can be used in Qt.

demo.name: Text Edit
demo.description: The Text Edit demonstration shows Qt's rich text editing facilities in action, providing an example document for you to experiment with.

demo.name: 40000 Chips
demo.description: This demo shows how to visualize a huge scene with 40000 chip items using Graphics View. It also shows Graphics View's powerful navigation and interaction features, allowing you to zoom and rotate each of four views independently, and you can select and move items around the scene.

demo.name: Embedded Dialogs
demo.description: This example shows how to embed standard dialogs into Graphics View. It also shows how you can customize the proxy class and add window shadows.

demo.name: Interview
demo.description: The Interview demonstration explores the flexibility and scalability of the model/view framework by presenting an infinitely deep data structure using a model and three different types of view.

demo.name: Rss Client
demo.description: This demo shows how to write a RSS news reader in QML.

demo.name: Twitter Client
demo.description: This demo shows how to write a mobile Twitter search client in QML. Use it to see what people think about Qt Quick!

demo.name: Browser
demo.description: The Web Browser demonstration shows Qt's WebKit module in action, providing a little Web browser application.

demo.name: Media Player
demo.description: The Media Player demonstration shows how <tt>Phonon</tt> can be used in Qt applications to handle audio and video playback.

demo.name: Boxes
demo.description: This demo shows Qt's ability to combine advanced OpenGL rendering with the the <tt>Graphics View Framework</tt>.

demo.name: Sub-attaq
demo.description: This demo shows Qt's ability to combine <tt>the animation framework</tt> and <tt>the state machine framework</tt> to create a game.
demo.tags: demo,sub-attaq,the animation framework,the state machine framework

demo.name: Spectrum Analyzer
demo.description: The Spectrum Analyzer demo shows how the <tt>QtMultimedia Module</tt> can be used in Qt applications to capture and then play back an audio stream.

demo.name: Minehunt
demo.description: This demo shows how to create a simple Minehunt game, using QML for the UI and C++ for the game logic.

demo.name: Vector Deformation
demo.description: This demo shows how to use advanced vector techniques to draw text using a <tt>QPainterPath</tt>.

demo.name: Books
demo.description: The Books demonstration shows how Qt's SQL classes can be used with the model/view framework to create rich user interfaces for information stored in a database.

demo.name: Main Window
demo.description: The Main Window demonstration shows Qt's extensive support for tool bars, dock windows, menus, and other standard application features.

demo.name: Spreadsheet
demo.description: The Spreadsheet demonstration shows how a table view can be used to create a simple spreadsheet application. Custom delegates are used to render different types of data in distinctive colors.

demo.name: SQL Browser
demo.description: The SQL Browser demonstration shows how a data browser can be used to visualize the results of SQL statements on a live database.

demo.name: Arthur Plugin
demo.description: In this demo we demonstrate the abilities of Qt's painting system in combination with Qt Designer's custom widget plugin facilities.

example.name: Animated Tiles
example.description: The Animated Tiles example animates items in a graphics scene.

example.name: Appchooser
example.description: The Application Chooser example shows how to use the Qt state machine and the animation framework to select between applications.

example.name: Easing Curves
example.description: The Easing Curves example shows how to use easing curves to control the speed of an animation.

example.name: Moving Blocks
example.description: The Move Blocks example shows how to animate items in a <tt>QGraphicsScene</tt> using a <tt>QStateMachine</tt> with a custom transition.

example.name: States
example.description: The States example shows how to use the Qt state machine to play animations.

example.name: Stickman
example.description: The Stickman example shows how to animate transitions in a state machine to implement key frame animations.

example.name: Map
example.description: The <tt>QtConcurrent</tt> Map example shows how to use the synchronous (blocking) <tt>QtConcurrent</tt> API to scale a collection of images.

example.name: Progress Dialog
example.description: The <tt>QtConcurrent</tt> Progress Dialog example shows how to use the <tt>QFutureWatcher</tt> class to monitor the progress of a long-running operation.

example.name: Run Function
example.description: The <tt>QtConcurrent</tt> Run Function example shows how to apply concurrency to a standard function, using <tt>QFuture</tt> instances to retrieve return values at a later time.

example.name: Word Count
example.description: The <tt>QtConcurrent</tt> Word Count example demonstrates the use of the map-reduce algorithm when applied to the problem of counting words in a collection of files.

example.name: Dynamic Scene
example.description: This example presents an interactive drag-and-drop scene. It demonstrates how to use QML's <tt>Dynamic Object Creation</tt> support to dynamically create and destroy objects.

example.name: Tic Tac Toe
example.description: This example presents a simple implementation of Tic Tac Toe.

example.name: Clocks
example.description: This example displays a set of clocks with different times for different cities. Each clock is created by combining <tt>Image</tt> elements with <tt>Rotation</tt> transforms and <tt>SpringAnimation</tt> behaviors.

example.name: Corkboards
example.description: This example presents a flickable set of interactive corkboards. It is created through a combination of elements like <tt>ListModel</tt>, <tt>Repeater</tt> and <tt>TextEdit</tt> together with rotation and scaling transforms, animation and mouse interaction.

example.name: TV Tennis
example.description: This example shows how to use animation components such as <tt>SpringAnimation</tt>, <tt>SequentialAnimation</tt> and <tt>PropertyAction</tt> to create a game of TV tennis.

example.name: Calculator Builder
example.description: The Calculator Builder example shows how to create a user interface from a Qt Designer form at run-time, using the QUiLoader class.

example.name: Calculator Form
example.description: The Calculator Form Example shows how to use a form created with Qt Designer in an application by using the user interface information from a QWidget subclass. We use uic's auto-connection feature to automatically connect signals from widgets on the form to slots in our code.

example.name: Container Extension
example.description: The Container Extension example shows how to create a custom multi-page plugin for Qt Designer using the <tt>QDesignerContainerExtension</tt> class.

example.name: Custom Widget Plugin
example.description: The Custom Widget example shows how to create a custom widget plugin for Qt Designer.

example.name: Task Menu Extension
example.description: The Task Menu Extension example shows how to create a custom widget plugin for Qt Designer, and how to to use the QDesignerTaskMenuExtension class to provide custom task menu entries associated with the plugin.

example.name: World Time Clock Builder
example.description: The World Time Clock Builder example shows how forms created with Qt Designer that contain custom widgets can be dynamically generated at run-time.

example.name: World Time Clock Plugin
example.description: The World Time Clock Plugin example shows how to create a custom widget plugin for Qt Designer that uses signals and slots.

example.name: System Tray
example.description: The System Tray Icon example shows how to add an icon with a menu and popup messages to a desktop environment's system tray.

example.name: Screenshot
example.description: The Screenshot example shows how to take a screenshot of the desktop using <tt>QApplication</tt> and <tt>QDesktopWidget</tt>. It also shows how to use <tt>QTimer</tt> to provide a single-shot timer, and how to reimplement the <tt>QWidget::resizeEvent</tt>() event handler to make sure that an application resizes smoothly and without data loss.

example.name: Configuration Dialog
example.description: The Config Dialog examples shows how a configuration dialog can be created by using an icon view with a stacked widget.

example.name: Extension Dialog
example.description: The Extension example shows how to add an extension to a <tt>QDialog</tt> using the <tt>QAbstractButton::toggled</tt>() signal and the <tt>QWidget::setVisible</tt>() slot.

example.name: Find Files Dialog
example.description: The Find Files example shows how to use <tt>QProgressDialog</tt> to provide feedback on the progress of a slow operation. The example also shows how to use <tt>QFileDialog</tt> to facilitate browsing, how to use <tt>QTextStream</tt>'s streaming operators to read a file, and how to use <tt>QTableWidget</tt> to provide standard table display facilities for applications. In addition, files can be opened using the <tt>QDesktopServices</tt> class.

example.name: Standard Dialogs
example.description: The Standard Dialogs example shows the standard dialogs that are provided by Qt.

example.name: Tab Dialog
example.description: The Tab Dialog example shows how to construct a tab dialog using the <tt>QTabWidget</tt> class.

example.name: Trivial Wizard
example.description: The Trivial Wizard example illustrates how to create a linear three-page registration wizard using three instances of <tt>QWizardPage</tt> and one instance of <tt>QWizard</tt>.

example.name: License Wizard
example.description: The License Wizard example shows how to implement complex wizards in Qt.

example.name: Class Wizard
example.description: The License Wizard example shows how to implement linear wizards using <tt>QWizard</tt>.

example.name: Draggable Icons
example.description: The Draggable Icons example shows how to drag and drop image data between widgets in the same application, and between different applications.

example.name: Draggable Text
example.description: The Draggable Text example shows how to drag and drop textual data between widgets in the same application, and between different applications.

example.name: Drop Site
example.description: The example shows how to distinguish the various MIME formats available in a drag and drop operation.

example.name: Fridge Magnets
example.description: The Fridge Magnets example shows how to supply more than one type of MIME-encoded data with a drag and drop operation.

example.name: Puzzle
example.description: The Drag and Drop Puzzle example demonstrates a way of using the drag and drop system with item view widgets.

example.name: Elastic Nodes
example.description: This <tt>GraphicsView</tt> example shows how to implement edges between nodes in a graph, with basic interaction. You can click to drag a node around, and zoom in and out using the mouse wheel or the keyboard. Hitting the space bar will randomize the nodes. The example is also resolution independent; as you zoom in, the graphics remain crisp.

example.name: Colliding Mice
example.description: The Colliding Mice example shows how to use the Graphics View framework to implement animated items and detect collision between items.

example.name: Diagram Scene
example.description: This example shows use of Qt's graphics framework.

example.name: Drag and Drop Robot
example.description: This <tt>GraphicsView</tt> example shows how to implement Drag and Drop in a <tt>QGraphicsItem</tt> subclass, as well as how to animate items using Qt's <tt>Animation Framework</tt>.

example.name: Ported Canvas
example.description: This <tt>GraphicsView</tt> example is a port of the old <tt>QCanvas</tt> example from Qt 3.

example.name: Ported Asteroids
example.description: This <tt>GraphicsView</tt> example is a port of the Asteroids game, which was based on <tt>QCanvas</tt>.

example.name: Pad Navigator Example
example.description: The Pad Navigator Example shows how you can use Graphics View together with embedded widgets and Qt's <tt>State Machine Framework</tt> to create a simple but useful, dynamic, animated user interface.

example.name: Shared Memory
example.description: The Shared Memory example shows how to use the <tt>QSharedMemory</tt> class to implement inter-process communication using shared memory. To build the example, run make. To run the example, start two instances of the executable. The main() function creates an <tt>application</tt> and an instance of our example's Dialog class. The dialog is displayed and then control is passed to the application in the standard way.

example.name: Local Fortune Client
example.description: The Local Fortune Client example shows how to create a client for a simple local service using <tt>QLocalSocket</tt>. It is intended to be run alongside the <tt>Local Fortune Server</tt> example.

example.name: Local Fortune Server
example.description: The Local Fortune Server example shows how to create a server for a simple local service. It is intended to be run alongside the <tt>Local Fortune Client</tt> example

example.name: Address Book
example.description: The address book example shows how to use proxy models to display different views onto data from a single model.

example.name: Basic Sort/Filter Model
example.description: The Basic Sort/Filter Model example illustrates how to use <tt>QSortFilterProxyModel</tt> to perform basic sorting and filtering.

example.name: Chart
example.description: The Chart example shows how to create a custom view for the model/view framework.

example.name: Custom Sort/Filter Model
example.description: The Custom Sort/Filter Model example illustrates how to subclass <tt>QSortFilterProxyModel</tt> to perform advanced sorting and filtering.

example.name: Color Editor Factory
example.description: This example shows how to create an editor that can be used by a <tt>QItemDelegate</tt>.

example.name: Combo Widget Mapper
example.description: The Delegate Widget Mapper example shows how to use a custom delegate to map information from a model to specific widgets on a form.

example.name: Directory View
example.description: The Dir View example shows a tree view onto the local filing system. It uses the <tt>QDirModel(obsolete)</tt> class to provide supply file and directory information.

example.name: Fetch More
example.description: The Fetch More example shows how two add items to an item view model on demand.

example.name: Frozen Column
example.description: This example demonstrates how to freeze a column within a <tt>QTableView</tt>.

example.name: Pixelator
example.description: The Pixelator example shows how delegates can be used to customize the way that items are rendered in standard item views.

example.name: Puzzle
example.description: The Puzzle example shows how to enable drag and drop with a custom model to allow items to be transferred between a view and another widget.

example.name: Simple DOM Model
example.description: The Simple DOM Model example shows how an existing class can be adapted for use with the model/view framework.

example.name: Simple Tree Model
example.description: The Simple Tree Model example shows how to create a basic, read-only hierarchical model to use with Qt's standard view classes. For a description of simple non-hierarchical list and table models, see the <tt>Model/View Programming</tt> overview.

example.name: Simple Widget Mapper
example.description: The Simple Widget Mapper example shows how to use a widget mapper to display data from a model in a collection of widgets.

example.name: Spin Box Delegate
example.description: The Spin Box Delegate example shows how to create an editor for a custom delegate in the model/view framework by reusing a standard Qt editor widget.

example.name: Star Delegate
example.description: The Star Delegate example shows how to create a delegate that can paint itself and that supports editing.

example.name: Basic Layouts
example.description: The Basic Layouts example shows how to use the standard layout managers that are available in Qt: <tt>QBoxLayout</tt>, <tt>QGridLayout</tt> and <tt>QFormLayout</tt>.

example.name: Border Layout
example.description: The Border Layout example shows how to create a custom layout that arranges child widgets according to a simple set of rules.

example.name: Dynamic Layouts
example.description: The Dynamic Layouts example shows how to move widgets around in existing layouts.

example.name: Flow Layout
example.description: The Flow Layout example demonstrates a custom layout that arranges child widgets from left to right and top to bottom in a top-level widget.

example.name: Arrow Pad
example.description: This example is a slightly more involved and introduces a key Qt Linguist concept: "contexts". It also shows how to use two or more languages.

example.name: Hello World
example.description: This example is a small Hello World program with a Latin translation. The screenshot below shows the English version.

example.name: Troll Print
example.description: Troll Print is an example application that lets the user choose printer settings. It comes in two versions: English and Portuguese.

example.name: Application
example.description: The Application example shows how to implement a standard GUI application with menus, toolbars, and a status bar. The example itself is a simple text editor program built around <tt>QPlainTextEdit</tt>.

example.name: Dock Widgets
example.description: The Dock Widgets example shows how to add dock windows to an application. It also shows how to use Qt's rich text engine.

example.name: MDI
example.description: The MDI example shows how to implement a Multiple Document Interface using Qt's <tt>QMdiArea</tt> class.

example.name: SDI
example.description: The SDI example shows how to create a Single Document Interface. It uses a number of top-level windows to display the contents of different text files.

example.name: Menus
example.description: The Menus example demonstrates how menus can be used in a main window application.

example.name: Recent Files
example.description: The Recent Files example shows how a standard File menu can be extended to show the most recent files loaded by a main window application.

example.name: Dial
example.description: This example shows how to create a dial-type control. It combines <tt>Image</tt> elements with <tt>Rotation</tt> transforms and <tt>SpringAnimation</tt> behaviors to produce an interactive speedometer-type dial.

example.name: Flipable
example.description: This example shows how to use the <tt>Flipable</tt> element.

example.name: Progress bar
example.description: This example shows how to create a progress bar.

example.name: Scroll bar
example.description: This example shows how to create scroll bars for a <tt>Flickable</tt> element using the <tt>Flickable::visibleArea</tt> properties.

example.name: Search box
example.description: This example shows how to combine <tt>TextInput</tt>, <tt>FocusScope</tt> and <tt>BorderImage</tt> elements to display multiple text input fields.

example.name: Slide switch
example.description: This example shows how to create a slide switch control.

example.name: Spinner
example.description: This example shows how to create a spinner-type component using the <tt>PathView</tt> element.

example.name: Tab widget
example.description: This example shows how to create a tab widget. It also demonstrates how <tt>property aliases</tt> and <tt>default properties</tt> can be used to collect and assemble the child items declared within an <tt>Item</tt>.

example.name: Blocking Fortune Client
example.description: The Blocking Fortune Client example shows how to create a client for a network service using <tt>QTcpSocket</tt>'s synchronous API in a non-GUI thread.

example.name: Broadcast Receiver
example.description: The Broadcast Receiever example shows how to receive information that is broadcasted over a local network.

example.name: Broadcast Sender
example.description: The Broadcast Sender example shows how to broadcast information to multiple clients on a local network.

example.name: Network Chat Client
example.description: The Network Chat example demonstrates a stateful peer-to-peer Chat client that uses broadcasting with <tt>QUdpSocket</tt> and <tt>QNetworkInterface</tt> to discover its peers.

example.name: Fortune Client
example.description: The Fortune Client example shows how to create a client for a simple network service using <tt>QTcpSocket</tt>. It is intended to be run alongside the <tt>Fortune Server</tt> example or the <tt>Threaded Fortune Server</tt> example.

example.name: Fortune Server
example.description: The Fortune Server example shows how to create a server for a simple network service. It is intended to be run alongside the <tt>Fortune Client</tt> example or the <tt>Blocking Fortune Client</tt> example.

example.name: FTP Client
example.description: The FTP example demonstrates a simple FTP client that can be used to list the available files on an FTP server and download them.

example.name: HTTP Client
example.description: The HTTP example demonstrates a simple HTTP client that shows how to fetch files specified by URLs from remote hosts.

example.name: Loopback
example.description: The Loopback example shows how to communicate between simple clients and servers on a local host.

example.name: Threaded Fort. Server
example.description: The Threaded Fortune Server example shows how to create a server for a simple network service that uses threads to handle requests from different clients. It is intended to be run alongside the Fortune Client example.

example.name: Torrent Client
example.description: The Torrent example is a functional BitTorrent client that illustrates how to write a complex TCP/IP application using Qt.

example.name: Secure Socket Client
example.description: The Secure Socket Client example shows how to use <tt>QSslSocket</tt> to communicate over an encrypted (SSL) connection. It also demonstrates how to deal with authenticity problems, and how to display security and certificate information.

example.name: Google Suggest
example.description: The Google Suggest example demonstrates how to use the <tt>QNetworkAccessManager</tt> class to obtain a list of suggestions from the Google search engine as the user types into a <tt>QLineEdit</tt>.

example.name: 2D Painting
example.description: The 2D Painting example shows how <tt>QPainter</tt> and <tt>QGLWidget</tt> can be used together to display accelerated 2D graphics on supported hardware.

example.name: Framebuffer Object
example.description: The Framebuffer Object example demonstrates how to use the <tt>QGLFramebufferObject</tt> class to render into an off-screen buffer and use the contents as a texture in a <tt>QGLWidget</tt>.

example.name: Framebuffer Object 2
example.description: The Framebuffer Object 2 example demonstrates how to use the <tt>QGLFramebufferObject</tt> class to render into an off-screen buffer and use the contents as a texture in a <tt>QGLWidget</tt>.

example.name: Grabber
example.description: The Grabber examples shows how to retrieve the contents of an OpenGL framebuffer.

example.name: Hello GL
example.description: The Hello GL example demonstrates the basic use of the OpenGL-related classes provided with Qt.

example.name: Overpainting
example.description: The Overpainting example shows how <tt>QPainter</tt> can be used to overpaint a scene rendered using OpenGL in a <tt>QGLWidget</tt>.

example.name: Pixel Buffers
example.description: The Pixel Buffers example demonstrates how to use the <tt>QGLPixelBuffer</tt> class to render into an off-screen buffer and use the contents as a dynamic texture in a <tt>QGLWidget</tt>.

example.name: Pixel Buffers 2
example.description: The Pixel Buffers 2 example demonstrates how to use the <tt>QGLPixelBuffer</tt> class to render into an off-screen buffer and use the contents as a dynamic texture in a <tt>QGLWidget</tt>.

example.name: Sample Buffers
example.description: The Sample Buffers example demonstrates how to use and enable sample buffers in a <tt>QGLWidget</tt>.

example.name: Textures
example.description: The Textures example demonstrates the use of Qt's image classes as textures in applications that use both OpenGL and Qt to display graphics.

example.name: Basic Drawing
example.description: The Basic Drawing example shows how to display basic graphics primitives in a variety of styles using the <tt>QPainter</tt> class.

example.name: Concentric Circles
example.description: The Concentric Circles example shows the improved rendering quality that can be obtained using floating point precision and anti-aliasing when drawing custom widgets. The example also shows how to do simple animations.

example.name: Font Sampler
example.description: The Font Sampler example shows how to preview and print multi-page documents.

example.name: Image Composition
example.description: The Image Composition example lets the user combine images together using any composition mode supported by <tt>QPainter</tt>, described in detail in <tt>Composition Modes</tt>.

example.name: Painter Paths
example.description: The Painter Paths example shows how painter paths can be used to build complex shapes for rendering.

example.name: SVG Generator
example.description: The SVG Generator example shows how to add SVG file export to applications.

example.name: SVG Viewer
example.description: The SVG Viewer example shows how to add SVG viewing support to applications.

example.name: Transformations
example.description: The Transformations example shows how transformations influence the way that <tt>QPainter</tt> renders graphics primitives. In particular it shows how the order of transformations affect the result.

example.name: Music Player
example.description: The Music Player Example shows how to use Phonon - the multimedia framework that comes with Qt - to create a simple music player. The player can play music files, and provides simple playback control, such as pausing, stopping, and resuming the music.

example.name: Audio Devices
example.description: The Audio Devices example demonstrates the basic use of <tt>QAudioDeviceInfo</tt> class provided with Qt.

example.name: Audio Output
example.description: The Audio Output example demonstrates the basic use of the <tt>QAudioOutput</tt> class provided with Qt.

example.name: Audio Input
example.description: The Audio Input example demonstrates the basic use of <tt>QAudioInput</tt> class provided with Qt.

example.name: Calendar
example.description: The Calendar example shows how to create rich text content and display it using a rich text editor.

example.name: Order Form
example.description: The Order Form example shows how to generate rich text documents by combining a simple template with data input by the user in a dialog. Data is extracted from a <tt>DetailsDialog</tt> object and displayed on a <tt>QTextEdit</tt> with a <tt>QTextCursor</tt>, using various formats. Each form generated is added to a <tt>QTabWidget</tt> for easy access.

example.name: Syntax Highlighter
example.description: The Syntax Highlighter example shows how to perform simple syntax highlighting by subclassing the <tt>QSyntaxHighlighter</tt> class.

example.name: Text Object
example.description: The Text Object example shows how to insert an SVG file into a <tt>QTextDocument</tt>.

example.name: Calculator
example.description: In this simple <tt>QtScript</tt> example, we show how to implement the functionality of a calculator widget.

example.name: Context2D
example.description: This Qt Script example is an implementation of the Context2D API.

example.name: Default Prototypes
example.description: This Qt Script example shows how to use default prototypes to make a non-<tt>QObject</tt>-based type scriptable.

example.name: Hello Script
example.description: The Hello Script example shows the basic use of Qt Script: How to embed a script engine into the application, how to evaluate a script, and how to process the result of the evaluation. The example also shows how to apply internationalization to scripts.

example.name: QSTetrix
example.description: The QSTetrix example is a Qt Script version of the classic Tetrix game.

example.name: Cached Table
example.description: The Cached Table example shows how a table view can be used to access a database, caching any changes to the data until the user explicitly submits them using a push button.

example.name: Drill Down
example.description: The Drill Down example shows how to read data from a database as well as submit changes, using the <tt>QSqlRelationalTableModel</tt> and <tt>QDataWidgetMapper</tt> classes.

example.name: Query Model
example.description: The Query Model example shows how to make customized versions of data obtained from a SQL query, using a model that encapsulates the query and table views to display the results.

example.name: Relational Table Model
example.description: The Relational Table Model example shows how to use table views with a relational model to visualize the relations between items in a database.

example.name: Table Model
example.description: The Table Model example shows how to use a specialized SQL table model with table views to edit information in a database.

example.name: Music Archive
example.description: The Master Detail Example shows how to present data from different data sources in the same application. The album titles, and the corresponding artists and release dates, are kept in a database, while each album's tracks are stored in an XML file.

example.name: SQL Widget Mapper
example.description: The SQL Widget Mapper example shows how to use a map information from a database to widgets on a form.

example.name: Event Transitions
example.description: The Event Transitions example shows how to use event transitions, a feature of <tt>The State Machine Framework</tt>.

example.name: Rogue
example.description: The Rogue example shows how to use the Qt state machine for event handling.

example.name: Traffic Light
example.description: The Traffic Light example shows how to use <tt>The State Machine Framework</tt> to implement the control flow of a traffic light.

example.name: Two-way Button
example.description: The Two-way button example shows how to use <tt>The State Machine Framework</tt> to implement a simple state machine that toggles the current state when a button is clicked.

example.name: Mandelbrot
example.description: The Mandelbrot example shows how to use a worker thread to perform heavy computations without blocking the main thread's event loop.

example.name: Codecs
example.description: The Codecs example demonstrates the principles behind importing and exporting text using codecs to ensure that characters are encoded properly, avoiding loss of data and retaining the correct symbols used in various scripts.

example.name: Completer
example.description: The Completer example shows how to provide string-completion facilities for an input widget based on data provided by a model.

example.name: Custom Completer
example.description: The Custom Completer example shows how to provide string-completion facilities for an input widget based on data provided by a model. The completer pops up suggestions for possible words based on the first three characters input by the user and the user's choice of word is inserted into the <tt>TextEdit</tt> using <tt>QTextCursor</tt>.

example.name: Internationalization
example.description: The Internationalization (I18N) example demonstrates Qt's support for translated text. Developers can write the initial application text in one language, and translations can be provided later without any modifications to the code.

example.name: Input Panel
example.description: The Input Panel example shows how to create an input panel that can be used to input text into widgets using only the pointer and no keyboard.

example.name: Plug and Paint
example.description: The Plug & Paint example demonstrates how to write Qt applications that can be extended through plugins.

example.name: Regular Expressions
example.description: The Regular Expressions (RegExp) example shows how regular expressions in Qt are applied to text by providing an environment in which new regular expressions can be created and tested on custom text strings.

example.name: Settings Editor
example.description: The Settings Editor example shows how Qt's standard settings support is used in an application by providing an editor that enables the user to view the settings for installed applications, and modify those that can be edited.

example.name: Tree Model Completer
example.description: The Tree Model Completer example shows how to provide completion facilities for a hierarchical model, using a period as the separator to access Child, GrandChild and GrandGrandChild level objects.

example.name: Undo Framework
example.description: This example shows how to implement undo/redo functionality with the Qt undo framework.

example.name: Analog Clock
example.description: The Analog Clock example shows how to draw the contents of a custom widget.

example.name: Calculator
example.description: The example shows how to use signals and slots to implement the functionality of a calculator widget, and how to use <tt>QGridLayout</tt> to place child widgets in a grid.

example.name: Calendar Widget
example.description: The Calendar Widget example shows use of <tt>QCalendarWidget</tt>.

example.name: Character Map
example.description: The Character Map example shows how to create a custom widget that can both display its own content and respond to user input.

example.name: Code Editor
example.description: The Code Editor example shows how to create a simple editor that has line numbers and that highlights the current line.

example.name: Digital Clock
example.description: The Digital Clock example shows how to use <tt>QLCDNumber</tt> to display a number with LCD-like digits.

example.name: Group Box
example.description: The Group Box example shows how to use the different kinds of group boxes in Qt.

example.name: Icons
example.description: The Icons example shows how <tt>QIcon</tt> can generate pixmaps reflecting an icon's state, mode and size. These pixmaps are generated from the set of pixmaps made available to the icon, and are used by Qt widgets to show an icon representing a particular action.

example.name: Image Viewer
example.description: The example shows how to combine <tt>QLabel</tt> and <tt>QScrollArea</tt> to display an image. <tt>QLabel</tt> is typically used for displaying text, but it can also display an image. <tt>QScrollArea</tt> provides a scrolling view around another widget. If the child widget exceeds the size of the frame, <tt>QScrollArea</tt> automatically provides scroll bars.

example.name: Line Edits
example.description: The Line Edits example demonstrates the many ways that <tt>QLineEdit</tt> can be used, and shows the effects of various properties and validators on the input and output supplied by the user.

example.name: Movie Player
example.description: The Movie example demonstrates how to use <tt>QMovie</tt> and <tt>QLabel</tt> to display animations. Now that Qt comes with the <tt>Phonon multimedia framework</tt>, <tt>QMovie</tt> is mostly useful if one wants to play a simple animation without the added complexity of a multimedia framework to install and deploy.

example.name: Scribble
example.description: The Scribble example shows how to reimplement some of <tt>QWidget</tt>'s event handlers to receive the events generated for the application's widgets.

example.name: Shaped Clock
example.description: The Shaped Clock example shows how to apply a widget mask to a top-level widget to produce a shaped window.

example.name: Sliders
example.description: Qt provides three types of slider-like widgets: <tt>QSlider</tt>, <tt>QScrollBar</tt> and <tt>QDial</tt>. They all inherit most of their functionality from <tt>QAbstractSlider</tt>, and can in theory replace each other in an application since the differences only concern their look and feel. This example shows what they look like, how they work and how their behavior and appearance can be manipulated through their properties.

example.name: Spin Boxes
example.description: The Spin Boxes example shows how to use the many different types of spin boxes available in Qt, from a simple <tt>QSpinBox</tt> widget to more complex editors like the <tt>QDateTimeEdit</tt> widget.

example.name: Styles
example.description: The Styles example illustrates how to create custom widget drawing styles using Qt, and demonstrates Qt's predefined styles.

example.name: Style Sheet
example.description: The Style Sheet Example shows how to use style sheets.

example.name: Tablet
example.description: This example shows how to use a Wacom tablet in Qt applications.

example.name: Tetrix
example.description: The Tetrix example is a Qt version of the classic Tetrix game.

example.name: Tool Tips
example.description: The Tool Tips example shows how to provide static and dynamic tool tips for an application's widgets.

example.name: Wiggly
example.description: The Wiggly example shows how to animate a widget using <tt>QBasicTimer</tt> and <tt>timerEvent()</tt>. In addition, the example demonstrates how to use <tt>QFontMetrics</tt> to determine the size of text on screen.

example.name: Window Flags
example.description: The Window Flags example shows how to use the window flags available in Qt.

example.name: Form Extractor
example.description: The Form Extractor example shows how to use <tt>QWebFrame</tt> with JavaScript to extract form data.

example.name: HTML Previewer
example.description: The Previewer example shows how to use <tt>QtWebKit</tt>'s <tt>QWebView</tt> to preview HTML data written in a <tt>QPlainTextEdit</tt>.

example.name: Fancy Browser
example.description: The Fancy Browser example shows how to use jQuery with <tt>QtWebKit</tt> to create a web browser with special effects and content manipulation.

example.name: Google Chat
example.description: The Google Chat example shows how to use implement a simple Google Chat client with <tt>QtWebKit</tt>.

example.name: SAX Bookmarks
example.description: The SAX Bookmarks example provides a reader for XML Bookmark Exchange Language (XBEL) files that uses Qt's SAX-based API to read and parse the files. The DOM Bookmarks example provides an alternative way to read this type of file.

example.name: DOM Bookmarks
example.description: The DOM Bookmarks example provides a reader for XML Bookmark Exchange Language (XBEL) files that uses Qt's DOM-based XML API to read and parse the files. The SAX Bookmarks example provides an alternative way to read this type of file.

example.name: RSS-Listing
example.description: This example shows how to create a widget that displays news items from RDF news sources.

example.name: QXmlStream Bookmarks
example.description: The QXmlStream Bookmarks example provides a reader for XML Bookmark Exchange Language (XBEL) files using Qt's <tt>QXmlStreamReader</tt> class for reading, and <tt>QXmlStreamWriter</tt> class for writing the files.

example.name: Recipes
example.description: The recipes example shows how to use <tt>QtXmlPatterns</tt> to query XML data loaded from a file.

example.name: QObjectXmlModel
example.description: This example shows how to use <tt>QtXmlPatterns</tt> to query <tt>QObject</tt> trees by modeling the non-XML data structure of a <tt>QObject</tt> tree to look like XML.

example.name: File Tree
example.description: This example shows how to use <tt>QtXmlPatterns</tt> for querying non-XML data that is modeled to look like XML.

example.name: Traffic Info
example.description: The WAP service used in this example is <tt>wap.trafikanten.no</tt> that is run by the Norwegian governmental agency for public transport in Oslo. The service provides real time information about the departure of busses, trams and undergrounds for every station in the city area.

example.name: XML Schema Validation
example.description: This example shows how to use <tt>QtXmlPatterns</tt> to validate XML with a W3C XML Schema.

tutorial.name: Address Book Tutorial
tutorial.description: This first part covers the design of the basic graphical user interface (GUI) for our address book application.
